skill.name: writing-clearly-and-concisely
skill.description: Use when writing prose humans will read—documentation, commit messages, error messages, explanations, reports, or UI text. Applies Strunk's timeless rules for clearer, stronger, more professional writing.
skill.summary: Apply Strunk's Elements of Style rules and avoid AI patterns to write clearer, more professional prose.
skill.author: softaworks

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only static markdown documentation files with no executable code. All 348 static findings are false positives caused by pattern-matching scanners detecting common words and syntax in markdown content. The skill provides writing guidance based on Strunk's Elements of Style and AI pattern avoidance.

dangerous_patterns.title: Pattern Matching False Positives in Markdown
dangerous_patterns.description: All 348 static findings are false positives. Pattern-matching scanners incorrectly flagged common words in markdown content as security issues. Examples include: 'encrypt' flagged as crypto vulnerability (but context is 'encoding text'), 'backtick' flagged as shell execution (but context is markdown code formatting), 'capture' flagged as screen capture (but context is capturing writing patterns), URLs in documentation flagged as hardcoded URLs.
dangerous_patterns.confidence_reasoning: Direct inspection of all skill files confirms this is a pure markdown writing guide with no executable code or network calls.

content.value_statement: AI-generated content often contains fluff, generic language, and unnecessary complexity. This skill applies Strunk's Elements of Style rules to produce clear, concise, professional writing while avoiding common AI patterns.
actual_capabilities: Applies Strunk's 18 rules for clear writing including active voice, positive form, concrete language, and omitting needless words
Identifies and eliminates common AI writing patterns like puffery, empty -ing phrases, and promotional adjectives
Improves documentation, commit messages, error messages, UI text, reports, and any prose humans will read
Provides context-efficient loading with progressive disclosure of reference materials
Cites specific style rules with examples from The Elements of Style (1918)
limitations: This skill provides writing guidance only; it does not execute code or access files
The skill cannot verify factual accuracy or technical correctness of content
Style recommendations may not suit all domains (legal, medical, creative writing have different conventions)
The skill does not provide grammar checking or spell checking; it focuses on clarity and concision

use_cases.title: Writing Technical Documentation
use_cases.description: Technical writers use this skill to produce clear API documentation, README files, and user guides that readers can actually understand.

use_cases.title: Crafting Git Commit Messages
use_cases.description: Developers use this skill to write concise, informative commit messages that clearly describe what changed and why.

use_cases.title: Creating User-Facing Text
use_cases.description: Product teams use this skill to write clear error messages, UI copy, and help text that users can understand and act on.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Documentation Draft
prompt_templates.prompt: Write documentation for [feature/topic]. Use this skill to ensure your writing is clear, concise, and avoids AI patterns. Focus on active voice, concrete language, and omit needless words.

prompt_templates.title: Editing Existing Text
prompt_templates.prompt: Edit this text for clarity and concision using the writing-clearly-and-concisely skill. Apply Strunk's rules: use active voice, put statements in positive form, use concrete language, and omit needless words. Also remove any AI patterns like puffery or empty -ing phrases.

prompt_templates.title: Writing Error Messages
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a clear error message for [situation]. The message should tell users what went wrong and what to do next. Keep it concise, avoid jargon, and use active voice.

prompt_templates.title: Reviewing AI-Generated Content
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this AI-generated content and edit it to sound more human. Remove puffery, promotional adjectives, empty phrases, and overly complex language. Make it direct and specific.

output_examples.input: This groundbreaking feature leverages cutting-edge technology to deliver a seamless experience, fostering better engagement and driving impactful results.
output_examples.output: This feature uses WebSocket connections to update the dashboard in real time.

output_examples.input: It is important to note that the API might potentially return an error in certain situations.
output_examples.output: The API returns an error when the token expires.

output_examples.input: The configuration file is read by the application at startup.
output_examples.output: The application reads the configuration file at startup.

best_practices: Be specific, not grandiose: Say what something does, not how important it is
Cut first, add later: Remove words until meaning suffers, then add back only what's needed
Prefer active voice: 'The function returns X' beats 'X is returned by the function'
anti_patterns: Using empty -ing phrases like 'ensuring reliability', 'showcasing features', 'highlighting capabilities'

faq.question: What writing rules does this skill teach?
faq.answer: The skill is based on Strunk's Elements of Style (1918). Key rules include: use active voice, put statements in positive form, use definite concrete language, omit needless words, keep related words together, and place emphatic words at end of sentence.

faq.question: What AI patterns should I avoid?
faq.answer: Common AI writing patterns include: puffery (pivotal, crucial, vital), empty -ing phrases (ensuring reliability), promotional adjectives (groundbreaking, seamless), and overused AI vocabulary (delve, leverage, multifaceted, foster, realm, tapestry).

faq.question: When should I use this skill?
faq.answer: Use this skill whenever writing prose for humans: documentation, commit messages, error messages, UI copy, reports, explanations, or any text that people will read.

faq.question: Does this skill check grammar?
faq.answer: No, this skill focuses on clarity, concision, and avoiding AI patterns. It does not check spelling, grammar, or punctuation. For grammar checking, use a dedicated grammar tool.

faq.question: How does context-efficient loading work?
faq.answer: The skill loads SKILL.md first (~1,000 tokens) with core rules. Reference files (1,000-4,500 tokens each) load only when needed. Most tasks need only 03-elementary-principles-of-composition.md.

faq.question: Can this skill help me sound less like an AI?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill includes guidance from Wikipedia's field-tested guide on detecting AI-generated content. It helps you avoid patterns that make writing sound robotic or generic.
